children.name: to read to understand written or printed words
read a1
children.definition: read to look at and understand the words in a book, magazine, letter etc for interest, enjoyment, or study :
examples: what book are you reading at the moment?
i usually read the newspaper on the way to work.
i can’t read your writing.
she picked up the letter and read it.
her books are quitewidely read(= read by a lot of people ).
when i was young, ireadevery one of his booksfrom cover to cover(= read all of something
read[s] c2informalukif you have a read, you spend time reading :
it's not brilliant but it's worth a read.
have a read
i sat down to have a nice quiet read .
could ihave areadof(= could i read) your newspaper, if you've finished with it?
read of
i had a quick read of the report before i left.
a good readsth that you enjoy reading :
i thought his last book was a really good read.
the book is agood/easyetc. read.

children.name: of a person: able to read
can read a1
children.definition: can read/kən ˈriːd/  có thể đọc
examples: ▪ tom could read by the age of four.
▪ very few people in the rural areas can read or write.

children.name: literate c2
children.definition: literate sb who isliteratecan read and write - use this aboutadultsorolderchildren:có học, biết đọc
examples: ▪ over the last hundred years, people have become healthier, more literate, and better educated.
▪ every student should be literate by the time he or she leaves primary school.
literacy[u] c1 the fact of being able to read - use this especially to talk about how many people in a society can read and in educational contexts: sự biết đọc
▪ cuba has one of the highest literacy rates in the world more people can read there than anywhere else in the world.
▪ literacy levels amongst girls very quickly overtook those of boys.
▪ she runs a project called ‘forward to literary’.
▪ special classes in basic skills such as literacy and numeracy

children.name: good reader x
children.definition: good/competent reader sb, usually achildwho can read well:người đọc tốt
examples: ▪ children are expected to be competent readers by the time they leave this class.
▪ good readers tend to be better at spelling than other children.

children.name: skim x
children.definition: skim to read sth quickly so that you get a general idea of what it is about:đọc lướt, đọc qua
examples: i skimmed the newspaper but didn’t see any report on the demonstration.
julie skimmed the sports page.
skim through/over
just skim through the second section to save time.
she didn’t have much time so she just skimmed through the report before the meeting.

children.name: scan c1
children.definition: scan to look through a text quickly in order to find a piece of information that you want or to get a general idea of what the text contains : đọc lướt
examples: she scanned the menu outside the restaurant, but decided it looked too expensive.
scan the newspaper article quickly and make a note of the main points.
scan sth for sth
robert scanned the lists for his name.
scan through
i scannedthroughthe booklet but couldn't find the address.
she scanned through the paper.

children.name: have a look at b1
children.definition: have a look atuk/take a look atus  to read sth quickly to check that there are nomistakesorproblems:nhìn lướt qua
examples: ▪ would you mind having a look at this report for me?
▪ i’ve had a quick look at the insurance contract and everything appears to be in order.
take a look at these figures - our profits are not looking good.

children.name: devour x
children.definition: devour to read books or literature quickly and eagerly: đọc ngấu nghiến
examples: she's a very keen reader - she devours one book after another.
he devoured science fiction books.
her young fans devour her books.

children.name: to read only parts of sth
thumb through x
children.definition: thumb/leaf/flipthrough sth to turn the pages of a book, magazine etc without reading much of it, looking for sth interesting or useful: dở qua, lật qua
examples: i began leafing through a magazine.
gloria lay on her bed and idly thumbed through the pages of a travel brochure.

children.name: dip into x
children.definition: dip into sth to read short parts of a book, magazine etc because you do not want to read the whole thing or because you are looking for a particular piece of information:xem lướt qua ( để tìm thông tin )
examples: he had some books by his bed which he would dip into when he couldn’t sleep.
this is a wonderful reference book to dip into for all sorts of fascinating information.
it's the sort of book you can just dip into now and again.

children.name: browse through b2
children.definition: browse through sthto spend time looking through a book, magazine etc without any clear purpose, looking for things that might interest you : lướt
examples: i was browsing through a magazine at the station bookstall when i noticed susan.
i was browsing through fashion magazines to find a new hairstyle.
would you like to browse through our holiday brochure?

children.name: flick through c2
children.definition: flick through sth to turn the pages of a book, magazine etc without reading much of it, looking for sth interesting or useful:lật qua
examples: she flicked through the guidebook, looking for somewhere to visit in the afternoon.

children.name: read through b2
children.definition: read through/over to read sth carefully especially in order to check every detail or find any mistakes:đọc từ đầu tới cuối, đọc hết
examples: it’s important to read through your essay before you finally hand it in.
my professor read over my dissertation and said that he was very impressed with it.
i’ve finished writing the report - i’ve just got to read it through now.

children.name: pore over x
children.definition: pore over sth to read sth for a long time, very carefully, and with great interest:đọc chăm chú, đọc kĩ, "miệt mài"
examples: he was sitting at his desk poring over old maps of the area.
ian shook his head as he pored over the report.

children.name: to read sth long or boring
plough through x
children.definition: plough through sthuk/plow through sthus  to read all of sth even though it takes a long time and is boring:cày
examples: i ploughed through all the documents related to the case
after plowing through so many huge textbooks it was a relief to pick up a novel again.

children.name: wade through x
children.definition: wade through to read sth that is very long and boring, or to read a lot of different pieces of writing such as letters, reports etc which together are long and boring to read:“lội bùn”
examples: we waded through a huge pile of applications, and finally selected six people to interview.
it’s much easier to find the information on the internet, rather than wading through piles of documents.

children.name: to read a lot about sth
read up on c1
children.definition: read up on to read a lot about sth or sb in order to find out about them: nghiên cứu
examples: i’ll need to read up on the rules of the game if i’m going to referee.
karen spent the summer reading up on the subjects she would be studying at college.
it's a good idea to read up on a company before going for an interview.

children.name: voracious reader x
children.definition: voracious/avid readeralsogreat/keen readerbritish  sb who enjoys reading and reads a lot:
examples: ▪ i was an avid reader as a child.
▪ my grandchildren are great readers, so i always give them books for their birthday.
voracious/avid reader of
▪ along with being an expert in business law, martin is a voracious reader of detective stories.

children.name: bookworm x
children.definition: bookworm informal sb who spends a lot of time reading:mọt sách
examples: ▪ i was a real bookworm when i was a child.
▪ an ideal gift for the bookworm in the family

children.name: well-read x
children.definition: well-read sb who iswell-readhas read a lot of books, often the most important or famous books, and has learned a lot of information from them: hiểu biết nhiều, đọc nhiều
examples: ▪ charles was a well-read and highly educated man.
well-read in
▪ although jack stopped his studies at 19, he was very well-read, especially in the classics.

children.name: of a person: unable to read
can’t read a1
children.definition: cannot/can’t read to be unable to read at all: không thể đọc
examples: ▪ a new report says that 25% of all 7-year-olds cannot read.
▪ jim couldn’t read at all until he was fifteen.
▪ it was not until i had lived with her for a year that i realized she couldn’t read.

children.name: illiterate c2
children.definition: illiterate sb who isilliteratecannot read or write - use this about adults or older children:mù chữ, thất học
examples: his father was an illiterate farm worker.
if 70% of the population is illiterate, how do people know who they are voting for?
illiteracy[u] the fact of being not able to read - use this especially to talk about how many people in a society cannot read:sự thất học, mù chữ
illiteracy rates among women in many countries are a serious cause for concern.
a society struggling to overcome poverty and illiteracy
the government has given extra funding to help tackle illiteracy in the inner cities.

children.name: slow reader x
children.definition: slow reader sb, especially a child, who can read, but not very well: người đọc chậm
examples: ▪ at first katy was a slow reader, but now she reads all the time.
▪ at the end of the day the teacher does half an hour’s extra work with the slow readers.

children.name: reference c1
children.definition: referencenounlook at; (sự) tham khảo
examples: [ u ] when you look at look at a book, piece of paper, etc in order to find information and help
_he made the whole speechwithoutreferencetothe notes in front of him.

children.name: to read and speak written or printed words
read a2
children.definition: read to say the words in a book, newspaper etc so that people can hear them
examples: read sb sth
daddy, will you read me a story?
read (sth) to sb
our mother reads to us every evening.
teachers should read more poetry to children.
read aloudto read sth and say the words so everyone can hear it:đọc lớn
he picked up the letter and began to read it aloud.
the poem is intended to be read aloud.
read aloud to/ from
sam read aloud from the note pinned to his door.

children.name: read out b2
children.definition: read out to read sth and say the words so that people can hear it:
examples: ▪ he opened the envelope and read out the name of the winner.
▪ read the numbers out and i’ll write them down.
read sth out to sb
▪ sarah read the letter out to me.
read out loud[vp] to read sth and say the words so everyone can hear it:đọc lớn
read out loud to/ from
after he went blind, she would read out loud to him from his favorite books.

children.name: read a1
children.definition: read to find out information from books, newspapers etc : đọc
examples: you can’t believe everything you read in the papers.
read about
did you read about what happened to that guy in florida?
read of
i was shocked when i read of his death.
read (that)đọc được rằng
i read last week that the disease is on the increase.

children.name: reading a1
children.definition: reading the activity or skill of understanding written words :kỹ năng đọc
examples: she loves reading.
reading is taught using a combination of several methods.
reading and tennis are my favourite pastimes.
make good (bedtime) reading(= are good to read (in bed at night)) .
the diariesmake good (bedtime)reading
compulsory/required reading
these books arecompulsory/requiredreading for students of architecture.

children.name: reading c2
children.definition: reading an occasion when something written, especially a literary work, is spoken to an audience : buổi đọc truyện, thơ
examples: poetry reading
a poetry reading at the bookstore
the society often arrangespoetryreadings and musical evenings.
